Benjamin, Geoffrey. 1976. Austroasiatic Subgroupings and Prehistory in the Malay Peninsula. In Austroasiatic Studies, 37-128. Honolulu: The University Press of Hawaii. ISBN 0-8248-0280-2
child.pub-comments: Benjamin himself does not call this group Southern Sekai. He writes that "Blagden's mention of 'Southern Sakai' dialects [...] suggests that forms intermediate between Semelai, Semaq Beri and Temoq might once have existed [...] (1976). He later discusses his own belief that there was some language Proto-Semaq Beri-Semelai-Temoq, leading one to believe there should be a subgroup here matching his description of Bagden's Souther Sakai.

child.publications: Benjamin, Geoffrey. 1976. Austroasiatic Subgroupings and Prehistory in the Malay Peninsula. In Austroasiatic Studies, 37-128. Honolulu: The University Press of Hawaii. ISBN 0-8248-0280-2
child.pub-comments: "Perhaps the 'Semaq Palaong' mentioned by Williams-Hunt (1952:44) belongs here [in Southern Sakai]" (Benjamin 1976).

child.publications: Benjamin, Geoffrey. 1976. Austroasiatic Subgroupings and Prehistory in the Malay Peninsula. In Austroasiatic Studies, 37-128. Honolulu: The University Press of Hawaii. ISBN 0-8248-0280-2

child.pub-comments: "Blagden suggests (1906:397) that [Mah Meri] is immediately related to [...] 'Orang Bukit of Ulu Langat' and 'Daley's Selangor Sekai" (Benjamin 1976).
